answers.author: Noel Bernal
answers.text:
Mark,  
What Roderick shared is correct. I would also add that in terms of budgeting,  an enterprise fund cannot be held to the same standards since one has to account for the future capital needs of the system for which the enterprise fund is set up for due to regulatory requirements (i.e. water, sewer, gas, etc.)  
The user fees should then account for the present and future needs of a system. The legal requirement is a cost of service method  
Another key area is that of the relationship between the general fund and an enterprise fund in terms of inter-fund transfer activity.   
My finance director and I recently put together a basic power point explaining the difference for new City Council members.   
Please select "City Council Presentation - General & Enterprise"  
http://ci.falfurrias.tx.us/index.php/city-government/document-center

answers.author: Roderick Wood
answers.text:
As it relates to budget cuts they have a point as they are a fee based service with legal criteria for the charge and use of those funds.  As it relates to budget format, public transparency, results, effectiveness and efficiency they should be held to the same budget and management standards.

answers.author: John Zakian
answers.text:
Mark, both Roderick and Noel are right on target.  I would add in the case of legal and policy framework for use of enterprise funds that there is nothing wrong holding enterprise fund managers to the same standards as anyone else especially in pressing for streamlining services to lower costs for same service delivery.  Enterprise funds should not be immune to such focus just because their revenues can't contribute to the general fund.  It is important to bear in mind that the public pays the fees as well as the local taxes.  Indeed, there can be circumstances where the overall impact on the public can and should be mitigated by reducing enterprise fees if local taxes need to be raised.  Sorry for the weak metaphor but everyone is in the same boat rowing in the same direction just using different oars.

author: Mark Abeles-Allison
text:
I am looking for some tips / resources on enterprise fund budgeting.  I understand the difference between the funds but am getting some feedback from enterprise fund managers that they should not be held to the same budgeting expectations as general fund departments.
Thanks for your help.
